questions.question: What type of wave is a sound wave?
questions.explanation: Sound waves are longitudinal waves because particles vibrate parallel to the direction of wave propagation, creating compressions and rarefactions.

questions.question: What is the approximate speed of sound in air at room temperature?
questions.explanation: Sound travels at approximately 340 meters per second in air at 20°C (68°F).

questions.question: Which property of sound determines its loudness?
questions.explanation: Amplitude determines loudness - greater amplitude means louder sound, measured in decibels (dB).

questions.question: What property of sound waves determines pitch?
questions.explanation: Frequency determines pitch - higher frequency means higher pitch, measured in Hertz (Hz).

questions.question: Why can't sound travel through a vacuum?
options: It requires a medium with particles
questions.explanation: Sound needs particles to vibrate and transfer energy. In vacuum, there are no particles to compress and rarefy.

questions.question: In which medium does sound travel fastest?
questions.explanation: Sound travels fastest in solids because particles are closer together and bonded more tightly, allowing faster energy transfer.

questions.question: What is the range of human hearing?
questions.explanation: Most humans can hear frequencies from about 20 Hz (low bass) to 20,000 Hz (high treble).

questions.question: What happens to the speed of sound when temperature increases?
options: It slightly decreases due to density
questions.explanation: Warmer air has faster-moving molecules that transfer vibrations more quickly, increasing sound speed by about 0.6 m/s per °C.

questions.question: What is an echo?
options: Transmission of sound through a medium
questions.explanation: An echo is a reflected sound wave that arrives at the listener after the direct sound, creating a repetition.

questions.question: What is the unit for measuring sound intensity level?
questions.explanation: Decibels measure sound intensity level on a logarithmic scale, with 0 dB being the threshold of hearing.

questions.question: Why does sound travel faster in water than in air?
questions.explanation: Water is denser than air, with particles closer together, allowing faster energy transfer between molecules.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the cochlea in the ear?
options: Convert sound vibrations to nerve signals
questions.explanation: The cochlea contains hair cells that convert mechanical sound vibrations into electrical nerve signals sent to the brain.

questions.question: What is ultrasound?
questions.explanation: Ultrasound refers to sound waves with frequencies above 20,000 Hz, beyond human hearing range.

questions.question: Why do sounds seem louder at night?
options: Air is cooler and denser near ground
People have better hearing at night
questions.explanation: Cooler night air near the ground is denser, creating a temperature inversion that refracts sound waves back toward the ground.

questions.question: What is resonance?
questions.explanation: Resonance occurs when an object vibrates at its natural frequency, causing large amplitude vibrations with little energy input.

questions.question: What is the difference between music and noise?
options: Music has regular patterns, noise is irregular
questions.explanation: Music consists of regular, predictable sound patterns, while noise is irregular and unpredictable.

questions.question: Why do whales use low-frequency sounds to communicate over long distances?
options: Low frequencies travel farther in water
questions.explanation: Low-frequency sounds experience less absorption and can travel hundreds of kilometers in water, unlike high frequencies that dissipate quickly.

questions.question: What is the role of the eardrum?
questions.explanation: The eardrum (tympanic membrane) vibrates when sound waves hit it, transferring these vibrations to the middle ear bones.

questions.question: What is the difference between infrasound and ultrasound?
options: Infrasound is below 20 Hz, ultrasound above 20,000 Hz
Infrasound is louder, ultrasound is softer
Ultrasound is only in medical use
questions.explanation: Infrasound refers to frequencies below 20 Hz, while ultrasound refers to frequencies above 20,000 Hz - both outside human hearing range.

questions.question: Why do concert halls use soft, porous materials on walls?
options: To absorb sound and reduce echoes
To make the room look nice
questions.explanation: Soft, porous materials absorb sound energy rather than reflecting it, reducing echoes and reverberation for clearer sound.
